Hexapod designed for use with 9G servos. It could be scaled up for larger servos, but this is my dev platform before I do that.

Lots of iterations. The Hexapod robot is pretty much defined by its geometry, so design choices are much more limited than many other types of robots.   
I hope the illustrations show the assembly well enough. I used servo mounting screws in the hole through the Servo horn, and 2.5m screws/nuts to mount the "regular bracket" to the "hip bracket".   
If you have questions about how to assemble it, feel free to ask.   
As to the code, I'm still working on it. You can probably adapt pre-existing code to it, and if so, just use the appropriate controller. I built this in order to build the code myself, for a learning process.

comments.text: I made a servo axis that attaches to the back of the servo and runs through the holes in the brackets, you can find it here - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1765131

author: jmcabey

description.text: collectible with initials through the bottom

After having a Jeweller severely scratch my watch trying to get the back off for a battery change, I've been quite paranoid about getting the battery done.  
It took me a while to figure out that with a 3D printer I can make my own tools, and being plastic, there's no chance of scratching them, so rather than buying a tool to do it myself, I made a quick design in solidworks and tried it out, and success.  
So I have two STL files uploaded, they suit my two watches, one being a casio with a 41mm diameter back, and the other a seiko watch with a 33.2mm diameter back. The actual part diameters are slightly larger.  
I added a half inch square drive to use with a ratchet, but I had success with just gripping the outside with my hand. These may also be scaled slightly, but there is a limit as the prongs will get smaller and become too weak and snap off.  
So this may not suit everyone, but it's mainly there to show that you can make the tool and swap batteries yourself, with the added advantage of not damaging it at all.  
Picture is of initial designs, the STL files are debranded.  
I printed on an ultimaker, laying flat.  
EDIT: Added V2 of the smaller one, after having a bit of difficulty using the older one. I'd Use that one ahead of the older file, but leaving it there anyway.

title: simple XY carriage for a custom H-Bot

description.text:
This is a simple XY carriage for a custom H-Bot my friend was building. (I just designed some printed parts for him).

This optimizes the print height to the maximum (as can be done from the XY carriage perspective)
The Fan duct is removable.

Uses:
E3d V6 hotend
LM8UU bearings
8mm smooth rods
30mm fan Use an M3 screw and nut to terminate the GT2 belt.

For the duct you will have to print with the fan mount facing the bottom. Then print till 2.2mm with 20-30% infill and the rest with only perimeters(suggested 2).
Then you would need to use a dremel or soldering iron tip to create the hole at the inside-end of the duct. I found this as the most suitable method. For your reference the Gcode i used is attached.

description.text: This file is from a 3d scan done by Taehoon Kim of a size 9 athletic shoe last.

Lasts are used in shoemaking to stretch leather into shoe forms. Athletic lasts like this one might be used to make many shoes and a lot of research, design and testing goes into their precise curves and dimensions. They define the all important "fit" of a shoe. Anyway, its a cool form. If you wanted to be a shoe designer you could scale this file up, hack it into pieces print it out and use it to start making patterns.

title: Dock for Nexus 4 and LG WCP300 wireless charger (parameterized)

description.text:
I got fed up with my Nexus 4 phone sliding out of position on its WCP300 wireless charger, so I decided to build something to keep them together.
I didn't want something to hold the phone at an angle, as I never use it in that way; it's just there for charging. This dock holds the phone fairly loosely so it can be lifted in and out without binding.
The dock was designed using OpenSCAD, and is parameterized, so can easily be adapted for other phones and wireless chargers (as long as the charger is round!). Apologies for the scruffy code - I simply wanted to get a one-off job done. :-)

Measure your phone and wireless charger, if you have something other than a Nexus4 and WCP300 charger. Also mount the phone on your charger so that it is charging reliably and then measure the distance from its base to the charger base. Add a millimetre or so to the phone and charger measurements, edit the OpenSCAD file to incorporate the new values and create an STL file. Note: the OpenSCAD code uses the word "puck" to describe the charger, simply because that's what it looks like!
If you do have both of these devices then simply slice the attached STL file and print. I used the following (but feel free to use whatever settings suit your machine and filament): CuraEngine slicer
0.3mm layer thickness
20% infill
PLA
210C hot-end, 60C bed
Full support enabled The STL files have 2 hollows underneath simply to save plastic - the support for these can be broken out after printing (but I didn't bother).

Here is a very simple design of a filament holder which isn't big and bulk and take's 30 mins to make the 2 you need. You can even print this with very little infill, I only used 10%. I designed this after needing one and all I could find where one's which looked over complicated for what I needed it to do so I designed this little one which works a treat and should work with all size filament spools. I have included a couple of feet which you can make out of ninja flex which work great if your printer is pulling the filament straight across instead of pulling the filament up. Here is a video of it working : https://youtu.be/keuVai_YIQ4

Print this on its side for the best results and print this with what ever settings you are happy to print with.  
I personally used 0.2mm at 40mm/s with 10% infill.
When printing the feet. Try to use kapton tape or something which will provide the foot with a shiny finish on the bottom as this produces the best amount of grip.

comments.text: Very nice and solid but they don't work well if your printer or setup doesn't pull the filament 'up' from the spool.  Trying to pull in any other direction pulls the spool off the holders.

title: Soda Pop Bottle Mosquito & Fly Trap

description.text:
I designed this trap to screw on to a standard 16 or 20 ounce pop bottle. It's got a recessed, narrowing opening just like most other bug traps, and there's a keyhole for hanging it on a drywall screw. The threads are "PCO-1881" and should fit many other containers.   
There's also a funnel to print. You can use this to fill the trap, some folks have also postulated that it makes it easier for pests to find the opening and enter the trap.   
Some sites recommend covering the traps with a sock, so that they're dark and welcoming to pests. It seems to work on spiders, but hasn't changed my results with mosquitoes as of yet.

I have successfully caught bees and flies, but I haven't figured out the right bait for mosquitoes yet. If you have something that works, please post it! So far, I've tried:
sugar water with yeast (brown and white sugar)
stagnant pond water
gatorade (has electrolytes like human sweat)
rotten orange juice
Hummingbird nectar
all of the above with a spritz of cologne/perfume
all of the above with yeast to produce CO2

comments.text: what combination has given you the best results?
comments.author: NEONX18

comments.text: I honestly haven't found the magical solution. It's easy to attract flies, but I just haven't had any luck with mosquitoes.
comments.author: NEONX18

comments.text:
they're attracted to carbon dioxide. try a mix of 1/4 cup of baking soda and 1 cup of vinegar. it'll foam and bubble up as it makes CO2. once the reaction stops, the bottle will slowly release the CO2 over time so long as the bottle stays upright (CO2 is heavier than air, but will gradually be displaced due to air movement).
set them a fair distance away so the mosquitoes don't get re-attracted to the people. use 3 or 4 in an arc around the point of activity.
comments.author: jimustanguitar

comments.text: I tried sugar water and yeast to generate CO2, which did bubble, but it didn't seem to do much for attracting bugs... I'll give the baking soda and vinegar trick a try. Nice idea.
comments.author: Spidor

comments.text: I like the built-in mount, I just wish the funnel entrance was just a little shorter. The overall length is not needed and it wastes material and print time.
comments.author: blingster

comments.text: http://www.independent.co.uk/news/smelly-cheese-joins-the-fight-against-malaria-1351230.html
comments.author: bdp68

comments.text: Interesting. Thanks!
comments.author: bdp68

comments.text: Mosquito season is here, once again. This year, I'm testing with a bait that I recently discovered. It's called Octenol, and I bought some on Amazon.
comments.author: jimustanguitar

comments.text: To follow up on this particular bait... I didn't notice a difference. It didn't seem like this smell did any better or worse than anything else I'd tried.
comments.author: jimustanguitar

comments.text: Maybe something to drip dilute vinegar into baking soda solution in the bottle to generate CO2 inside the bottle?
comments.author: n5ima

comments.text: drip isn't necessary; the co2 is heavier than air, and will stay in after its released. it will gradually be displaced by moving air (eduction) and attract mosquitoes for a good long while.
comments.author: n5ima

comments.text: Mosquito abatement use pieces of dry ice, which mimic the CO2 of a human's breath (as mentioned below). I have an electric mosquito catcher that uses these bulbs: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000FGNLT6?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o05_s00. Anything that emits that type of light will attract them. Not sure the GITD filament will work... but if it did, let me know :-)
comments.author: dgwinner

comments.text: Mosquitoes are very fine tuned for human breath CO2
comments.author: juancarlospaco

comments.text: Mosquitoes are also attracted to heat, so maybe a small electric heating element combined with yeast (for CO2) might help.
comments.author: bovine

comments.text: Awesome!! I would love to know how it goes. I have a pond out the back and don't have enough mosquito's out there to warrant buying a mozzie zapper but if this works it would take care of the few that I get. Keep me posted on how it goes. Cheers
comments.author: Rapidhearts

comments.text: mosquitoes are attracted to light so maybe put a low voltage led in there somehow. or make it out of glow in the dark filament. I don't know if that would make them smart enough to go in the bottle though. But maybe a combination of bait and light might help
comments.author: Rapidhearts

comments.text: Great idea. I just picked up some glow in the dark filament, so I'll have to give that a try! Thanks.

author: raskal

description.text:
How it works? Cold Box is made of two cylinders one inside the other.
Inner cylinder has no holes to ensure contents remain dry. The gap between the innter and outer cylinder is filled with a metarial such as sand, wool or soil, that can be soaked with water. In hot weather the sun's rays heats this wet metarial and the water evaporates off. As the metarial is held against the inner cylinder wall, heat is removed from innter chamber by the evaporation precess, keeping it at a tempature of a cool. Inspired by Emily Cummins' solar-powered fridge invention.

description.text: The iconic bird that went from ark scout to international peace symbol. Print your own salute to world peace! I have also made a version to suspend from the ceiling or hang in a mobile: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1034386 The text I put on it is in Dutch, and translates to 'peace and good things', the signature greeting of Franciscan followers, like my grandmother, for whom I made this sculpture. I only included the blank version here. The bird itself was not modelled by me; all props go to a guy called Peter Behrens on http://archive3d.net/?a=download&id=58b6be71 . I just made the stand and the branch, and made it more print-ready. Depending on how you print it, you need hardly any support material. Some afterprint love is required though - which is only symbolically justifiable. If you make one, please share the results!

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.4 nozzle, 0.1 layer height

Infill:

30% with 30% overlap

Notes: 3MM PLA, Ultimaker Original

I have uploaded two versions: one with the complete dove in one piece, and one where the bird is split in twine for easier printing. Choose whichever fits your printer better; the full model will need extensive support, the split model only a bit.  
The feathers are very thin; your printer (just like mine) might have problems printing them. I scaled the model in the direction of wing thickness to 120%, which made it just that tiny bit stronger around the wing tips. It's barely noticeable in the dove's body.  
The two parts were connected using super glue, which works like a charm. The holes in the model I carefully drilled out with a 2mm drill, just enough for the branch to fit through and the stand to connect to the bird.   
If you're handy with CAD modelling, print your own text on the stand. As I want to share the design, there's no sense in leaving the dutch text on it for everyone.

title: Toilet Paper Roll Holder with Phone Holder

description.text:
A toilet paper roll holder with a modular phone holder. I tackled a very very prevalent issue that occurs both at home and in the workplace. I noticed that most people (even myself) take their phones with them when they go to use the restroom, and a handful of them will leave their phones in the restroom because they place it somewhere they can't see it and forget about it. To address this issue, I designed a modular toilet paper roll holder that can be used to hold cell phones. I am currently redesigning the model to strengthen the modular parts that hold the phone. Currently, one of the parts is a little weak and can get loose, causing the whole assembly to slump when some force is applied. Things to fix:
Connection between holder and module
Connection sizing SolidWorks files are available if you would like to edit/modify them on your own! Just shoot me a message and I'll send them over to you.
Updates Coming Soon! **10/7/15
Updated Module and Roll Holder! It holds up a lot better now!

title: Xbox One Privacy Cover for Kinect

description.text: This is a privacy cover for the Xbox One Kinect.  It has two pieces and can print with no supports.  It needs no extra parts other that what is printed.  The hinge is fully movable to the down privacy position and then to the up viewing position.  The assembly slides on to the end on the Kinect and can be fully removed at any time with no damage.  I have it on mine and it works great.

I positioned this so you should not need supports.  I used a 5% fill on a Makerbot 5th generation PLA printer.  The two parts print independently of each other, then snap together to create a working hinge.  
Build Position:  For the back piece, make sure the short flat is on the build plate.  This will put the hinge  at he top, but don't worry, you don't need supports.  The front piece is the same.  position it so the hinge is at the top.

The paper test, while a useful thing, just isn't my cup of tea. I want numbers. Two models are listed here.  
Do keep in mind that the Overlord Pro was sold with a Z resolution of 100 micron.  Don't freak out when you can't get 100% repeat-ability.  Dial indicators measure very small changes and that needle sweeps a lot at even 50 micron/.002in.  Dial indicators themselves have some tolerance issues too.  So the combination of backlash, endstop repeatability, and dial indicator inaccuracies add up to a lot.  
1) V2 is a conical shaped mount designed to fit a 1" range dial indicator. It will clamp onto the shoulder of the dial indicator and has a 9.4mm diameter clamp.  It'll hold a 3/8 (9.525mm) nice and snug if your filament has some give.  Use a 3mmx20mm screw to clamp it shut.  A relief is in place for a 3mm nylock (5.5mm from fla to flat) as well.  If you're printing in PLA, use the other mount.  
2) V1a is a bracket that will hold pretty much any dial indicator out there that has a mounting tab on the back of it, and is more or less the same dimension-ally as a Mitsumi analog dial indicator.  The through slot is 3.5mm in width by design.  The accompanying slop gives you the wiggle room to move the dial indicator around until it is perfectly centered through the hole on the mounting plate.  I use a 3mmx25mm screw to clamp the dial indicators tab in place.   The gap between the "towers" is 7mm.  
The "towers" are positioned so that the dial indicator faces the "front" of the printer for easy reading.  
The "towers" are of different thickness by design. One was thinner than I would have liked, and compensated by making the other thicker.

This circular loom is perfect for knitting hats! I have one just like it that I bough on a whim from Tchibo and that I haven't put down since. Even there are already a few on Thingiverse, none of them are very good for the kind of hats that I like to make, so I thought I would share this ingenious little design with you guys. I changed a couple things from the original to make it printable without supports. Print the loom and then the hook and needle. Knitting instructions:
Take some wool and tie a loose knot around the base. Then, moving in an anticlockwise direction from one peg to the other, wrap the wool around the next peg in a clockwise loop. Do this to the next one and the next until you have a single row of loops. Push the loops down a little and then make a second row above the first. Then, using the hook, pull the first/lower loop on each peg, over the second/higher loop and over the head of the peg. Then let it drop and move onto the next peg. Once you only have only one row of loops on all the pegs, put down the hook/hold it between your teeth/stick it behind your ear and use your hand to make another wool row. Repeat until you have a long enough tube. Remember, you probably want to fold back the first few rows once you put it on your head to form a cute little fold, so make sure to account for that (10 extra rows is usually sufficient).
Once you are sure you have the desired length, cut about 1m of the wool, thread it through the needle and go through the last row of loops "doubled-up", simply allowing the loop to slide up over the needle, onto the tread and off the peg. Tighten.
Sow on a pom pom and voila!

title: Gen6 Electronics Mount Plate for Prusa Mendel

description.text: This is a clip-on electronics mounting plate for the Prusa Mendel. The plate is designed for holding a Gen6 electronics board, but it can be modified to keep any other electronics as well.

In order to print this you need a print volume of at least 260mm in X (or Y) direction - it just fitted on my RepStrap machine. The distance of the clips is 248mm, which should fit exactly on a Prusa Mendel. The stl-file is ready for printing, i also attached the scad-file for modifications. Some possible improvements:
  • The material strength above and below the center hole is too low, causing the plate to easily bend. Maybe also the material thickness of the plate (only 2mm) should be increased a bit.
  • The material strength of the clips is a little too low, especially when you have some problems with oozing (as you can see in the picture).

comments.text: What Prusa or Mendel has a 260mm bed?
comments.author: MrJohn

comments.text: I printed it on my bootstrapping machine (based on WolfStrap), which can print up to 263mm in x-axis.

Easy to use , just update parameter :
// Description parameter
Nb_sphere = 3; // number of sphere (Vertical one not include)

This is a Y-axis idler for the P3steel 2.x.
Designed for use with 2 pieces MF126 bearings. This part corrects the geometrical failure of the original part.
The belt will run perfectly horizontal and parallel when used with a 20teeth pulley. This part is a remix of my first idler and now compatible with P3steel 2.x versions. It's now more rigid and precise. It's the next part of a complete series for P3steel parts.
I redesigned every part based on my long time experience with the P3 steel. Please share your makes! http://scheuten.me/?p=429

comments.text: Works great for me, thanks for sharing. I used an M5 screw as that matched the idler that I had. It took a bit of work to clean up the inside to fit the idler in, but I think my printer had just been a bit over-enthusiastic with support material. Thank you!
comments.author: dtengineering

comments.text: Thanks ... but ... all of my parts are printable without support material!
comments.author: dtengineering

comments.text: You are using an M6 screw? because by default I got an M8
comments.author: DemianR

comments.text:
Could you please give me the printer settings to be used?
Thank you
comments.author: Andybi

comments.text: Is there an advantage to using the the flanged bearings over using a matched 20 tooth timing belt pully such as this:https://www.amazon.com/gp/aw/d/B0188HW4Z0/ref=psd_mlt_nbc_B0188IFK4Q_b
comments.author: Malatang

comments.text: if running high belt tension ...a smooth pulley will damage your belt teeth (compressing those teeth, compression set). I have printers with both smooth and toothed idler pullies .. I use toothed pulley idlers with steel corded GT2 belts which require very high belt tension.
comments.author: Malatang

comments.text: I tested this long long time ago. I didn't see any difference.
comments.author: Malatang

comments.text:
The MF126 bearing is a good choice and matches the OD of a 20 tooth GT2 pulley.
I got the MF126 bearing here: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00HHHDQLE?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o08_s00
& belt + pulley here: http://www.aliexpress.com/item/Free-Shipping-2Pcs-20-GT2-6-GT2-Pulley-And-2m-GT2-6mm-Open-GT2-Belt-for/1952469633.html The MF126 is flanged with two making a good guide for the G2 Belt.
comments.author: ctchunter1

comments.text: The insert size is absolutely correct. If you have some space left you don't have a precise printed part or the wrong M3 nut.

I might remount it a little later.

We are publishing our version of filament winder.
We based on the original code of Ian Johnson.
It is an excellent system with good stability.
Our system can hold up to two spools at the same time. We have design also a geared-cone to hold our previous published spools.
With that you can use the extruder and make spools of 50 meters.
Visit us at filamake.com.
By printing the files you must understand that it needs a lot of work to make it play. The whole system is a remix. Thanks to many of you by using your files to create the filamake winder. We have two versions:
V1. Most of the parts are 3d prints
V2. Most of the parts are laser cut. We will publish also the laser cut version.
We have include many different files which can help anyone to adjust and setup correctly the system. We have add two types of holders for spool motor. We use a dc one but you can add a step motor instead of dc. Also you are welcome to readjust and redesign the whole system. You can ask for electronics from us to complete the winder Video with winder assembled and working

title: Brotherhood of Nod Keyholder (Command and Conquer)

description.text: A simple key holder that you can place on your wall once completed and hang your keys off of via a pair of magnets located at the bottom.

I started in CorelDRAW X7 and brought over my reference image for the logo. I then traced out the outline for both the outline, as well as the inside logo. Upon bringing it into 3ds Max, the design gave me three separate meshes: the scorpion tail, the the outline, and the inner part of the outline the needed to be sucked out. I extruded all three pieces out, making the tail and outline 2.5, and the inner portion 1.5. I then lined up the inner portion with the outline and boolean subtracted out the interior, leaving me with space for which I can place the scorpion tail. I moves the tail into place and boolean combined the two meshes.I then sized the magnets I was going to use (7-8 mm in diameter and 2 in depth) and I created two simple cylinders to fit the description. After properly proportioning the cylinders, I had to resize my mesh. The most accurate way of doing this is bringing it into the print preview for your 3d printer and judge for yourself the scale that you want.
Once I got the proper size for the mesh, I booleaned out the cylinders and then capped them. All that was left to do was print it.
After it was printed, it was simply a matter of sanding and painting it. Paint colours vary, but I went for a black primer, followed by a silver outline and red interior to attempt to make it look as cool as possible.
Hope you guys like it, and remember to have fun with the mesh! If you found a cool way that you adapted my mesh to make it your own then please share with me!

So you all heard they are making an "Ender's Game" movie right?  Due out in Novemeber.  What better way to show your love of the story than to show up with an Ender's Game Necklace!!!

The logo's them self are from the released images of the Army logos.  I just used Inkscape to make a SVG for each.  The IF logo was was more difficult.  All the images of it have a gradient in the background that doesn't take kindly to Inkscape's path finding.  So I broke out my Tinkercad skills and whipped up my own version.  
After I got the base logos, I just used Tinkercad to make them into necklaces.

title: 1 1/4 to 5/8" hose adapter. Hydro-Force (Candian Tire) soft-sided pool pump hose adapter

description.text:
I built a simple pool heater for our 12' Hydro-Force soft-sided pool from Canadian Tire. I bought some black poly hose to make a solar water heater. It was labeled 1/2" i.d. but I found that it's inner diameter was actually 5/8" (measure twice, print once). This adapter fits between the hose for the pump and the hose for the heater.  
Tapered sides so that it didn't have to be perfect.
*UPDATE: I wasn't happy with the original, the taper wasn't gradual enough to help and interfered with clamping. I've added a new one with flat sides.

title: Slot Extender For Logitech K480 Bluetooth Keyboard (Use with Samsung Note 12.2)

description.text:
I bougth a Logitech K480 Bluetooth keyboard for my wifes iPad, works good. Then I tried to use the keyboard with my Samsung Note 12.2 and I found out that the slot is to small to use the tablett in landscape mode. So I designed two small adapters which extends the slot and so the Note 12.2 can be used with this keyboard.
Pretty simple...
The externders need a little bit force to slip into the slot. Depends on you printers resolution. It could be neccesary to scale down the stl file maybe to 0,95 percent.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes: Shell is printed 1,6mm due to the heavy load of the tablet.
